The Venturer Program: Resurgence

------------------------------

The success of the first manned missions to the planets in over a decade has been met with great relief; the Venturer Program has captivated the minds of all those with their eyes turned skywards. There is one more mission planned for the MSV Venturer before the re-colonisation of Duna takes place, and it is to explore one of the more recent geological formations of the red planet. However, a dark shroud looms over the space program; the revelation of continued Firespitter activity has raised alarm bells with many, prompting investigations that could tip a precarious stalemate over the edge at any momentÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

------------------------------

Prologue

Chapter 1: The fourth planet

Chapter 2: Descent

Chapter 3: Investigations

Chapter 4: A volcano in my back yard

Chapter 5: Mount Volcas

Chapter 6: Elite

Chapter 7: Dilemma

Chapter 10: The show must go on -- Part One

Chapter 15: Firespitter

Epilogue

------------------------------

PROLOGUE

Several months after the second Venturer mission. A tape from several weeks after the mission is playing on the television, with Buzz, Gene, and Lengas sat at the far end of the room.

KIN Reporter: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So tell me, President Booker, can you shed any light at all on this Krumer Conspiracy? We already know that he was ousted for corruption, but there seems to be more behind this tale than youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re letting on.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Booker: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, as much as IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d love to reveal this information to the public, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s currently a very fragile situation weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve found ourselves, so I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t elaborate.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KIN Reporter: Ã¢â‚¬Å“But we already know of the involvement of Krumer with Firespitter Company, a group renowned for their aggressive tactics in any matter theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re called into. If they still owe their allegiance to KrumerÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Booker: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Look, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m going to have to stop you there. There is seriously nothing I can say on this matter without tipping a very delicate stalemate. Hell, if this interview even goes live, we could have trouble.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KIN Reporter: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is that so?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Booker: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, so IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d advise that you cease the investigation into the matter for now. I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t want to sound rude, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the only way.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KIN Reporter: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You seem quite determined to avoid revealing anything, Mr. President.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Booker: Ã¢â‚¬Å“This isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t the Kraken War; we arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t in any mortal danger. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re faced with a political conspiracy, and that is something that needs more care and attention than simply blowing alien spacecraft out of the sky. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sorry I couldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t help make the front page of the newspapers, but hopefully it will become clear in time.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The tape flickers to an end.

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s really that delicate?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm. Then again, military ops are usually like this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know that, I was in the air force.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Who says this is a military operation?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It certainly seems that way. Besides, if it werenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t, why would I have been given a starfighter, and why would we only just be watching this video?

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, good points.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re getting slow, man.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Shut up.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Heh.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, this is all ridiculous. If we just reveal what theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re doing, then theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be paralysed by the metaphorical spotlight pointed at them.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nothing you can do though. YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re just going to have to fly that ship. You arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t alone though, are you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think they have 3 other guys whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be in orbit as well as myself. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a point, when am I going up in thisÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s it called again?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s an MSI A87 Arrow light fighter.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“As for your launch time, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be heading up into orbit in 12 hours, so IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d suggest getting some rest now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Probably a good idea; I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t want to be getting sleepy on a secret mission.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That would be problematic.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“DidnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t you say you were heading off to the astronaut complex?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I said in 5 minutes.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That usuallyÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ never mind.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Man, I remember my starfighter flights. I canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t say any were more eventful than the first Mechani-Kraken incident, though. That was heart-pounding.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I still maintain that you were reckless that day, Lengas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I survived, didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t I?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Only because youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re a damn good pilot that knew the engineering aspects of your ship.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Too right. To be fair though, I do remember some guys more reckless than myself. There was a session of War Games in LKO involving a couple of fighters, and some of the pilots actually took their ships about a dozen kilometres into the atmosphere. They got out alright, but they ended up with severe reprimands. That was, hmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ 32 years agoÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ geez, that was when Outreach Colony was being planned out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh, I still maintain that youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re the most reckless IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve seen.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Fine then, doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t bother me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Gene: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I suppose IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d better go and check on the progress of the Venturer. They should have been in DunaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s SOI for a while now. Buzz, get some rest, and LengasÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ just donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t go and get into too much trouble, would you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh ha ha. Catch you later, Gene.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Come on, I could use a drink right about now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sure thing, buddy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

------------------------------

Crew, MSV Venturer:

Franklin: Captain of MSV Venturer, mission commander, pilot. Enlisted from test flight program.

Sigler: Ship doctor. Enlisted from med school.

Scott: Pilot and trajectory planner. Enlisted out of the air force.

Hans: Engineer. Enlisted from university.

Mernie: Geologist, some medical expertise. Spent time studying samples from Mun and Minmus.

Hmm, it's quiet around here, not that I'm concerned or complaining... maybe I ought to be concerned, though. You could have all been systematically assassinated, for all I know, and that would be a pretty bad situation to find myself faced with. I could even be next on the hit list...

Or I could blame Christmas for distracting you from the true path of enjoying my glorious story. Maybe even those advent calendars that carry on until New Year's Eve could have you occupied. The list of potential explanations goes on and on

...

As for the story, I suppose I can administer a bit more information about the schedule; it's going to be quite slow. I have a few chapters written up and waiting for posting, but I suddenly realised I have an overwhelming amount of pictures, mostly from the last part of the story which I finished off in-game today (this bit should be pretty good ). You're going to have to be patient, I'm afraid... that is if you haven't become subject to any of the aforementioned distractions or inconveniences, which would be problematic, really.

I can give you an explanation for myself: the amount of time I am allowed on the Internet has decreased quite a bit for me. Thus, I have to choose between the forums and writers like you and YouTube and players like Scott Manley. Most of the time I choose Scott, but every once in a while I check in here.
Oh boy! You're back! I'll be reading this!
Cool first chapter. Addicted already, even w/o the images.

Oh, I was just chased through downtown Tokyo by the Illuminati. No worries.

I like your stories, they're one of my inspirations!

Oh, I was just chased through downtown Tokyo by the Illuminati. No worries.

Systematic assassination, just like I said. Looks like I'll need to rent that sniper rifle after all.

CHAPTER 1: THE FOURTH PLANET

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Control, be advised, we are one hour from Duna aerobrake, over.Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Copy that, Franklin. Everything else alright out there?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“EverythingÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s fine, thanks for asking. What about on your end?Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, the final components went up for the MSV Enterprise; we can anticipate launching her mission in a few months once everything is cleared. Other than that, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been relatively dull.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Have Firespitter tried to pull any stunts lately?Ã¢â‚¬Â

KSC: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not sure, but weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re still investigating.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, thanks control, Venturer out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sounds promising.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know, those Firespitter guys are slippery. Just as we get a lead, it fades away into nothing or something completely different. I tell you, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re good at leading a wild goose chase.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I can agree with that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m still uncertain about the security of this mission. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve made good progress so far, but the way theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been going, they could have snuck out here and got a few nasty surprises waiting for us.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Doubtful, but I guess theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve done some sneaky damages already, so who knows?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, if they screw with my missionÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HavenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t we talked about this already?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m just reiterating, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s all.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m honestly more concerned about our landing site. It seems a bit risky, if you ask me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The volcano? That thing hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t erupted for years, has it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t actually thinking of that, but I guess itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s another thing to worry about; it could go off again while weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re thereÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“At which point weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll haul ass in the lander and get back to orbit. If itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s crashing into the side of the mountain youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re concerned about, then you neednÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t worry; not only did the unmanned equipment manage it, but weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve got good pilots and Stanley to help us out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed, I will assist with the descent. You have nothing to fear, Mernie.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That coming from an AI that went half-psychotic a few months ago.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That was an overreaction. It will not happen again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No doubtÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Anyway, come on guys, we need to prepare for this aerobrake.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed we do.Ã¢â‚¬Â

One hour laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Solar panels have retracted successfully.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Two minutes until atmospheric entry.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Get everything secured back there if it isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t already, and then get seated.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know the drill. Of course, securing everything would mean leaving me bored out of my brains, seeing as no-one will get injured by a flying toothbrush or somethingÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You actually wantÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, of course not! ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a good thing that no-one has been hurt under my watch on these missions, but it also means that IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m reduced to helping with tasks that I have little knowledge about. Believe me, that can get very boring very quickly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, I see your point.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t worry, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll find something to keep yourself occupied.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No doubt about that; I managed on Dres.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“At least you got to go down to the surface of that asteroid; I could have left you in orbit instead of taking you down with me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“CanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t complain then, can I?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“One minute.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Got it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Half an hour laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Inclination change complete; we are now aligned with Ike. The landing site will be in daylight in a few orbits time.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s get the lander ready to go. Hans, come give me a hand.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be through in a moment.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Beginning lander power-up sequence. All systems nominal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a good start. I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know what weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going to do if this thing fails on us; Project Nebula is sort of riding on this lander working.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Even though this one is just for use on Duna.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well yeah, but if this lander works, then the one being used on the Enterprise will be cleared for use on worlds ranging from Gilly to Duna, size-wise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Scott: Ã¢â‚¬Å“True enough.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know whatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s more exciting; re-colonising Duna or Project Nebula.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d say Nebula, personally, but thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s because IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m a pilot, and a pilot canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t do much when seated in a base on a dusty rock.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You have a point, but imagine it; Outreach 2.0. That would be pretty impressive. Plus theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re also thinking of re-using the Venturer landing sites as small bases.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That makes sense. Why make more sites if you have some already?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Exactly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh, not for me to worry about right now, anyway. I just need to make sure I get Hans and Mernie down to the ground in one piece.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Which would be much appreciated.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m sure it would be.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mernie, is there anything youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re unsure of, or do you think you can take care of their boo-boos down there?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be alright, Sigler.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sigler: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then, but give me a shout over comms if you need help.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll bear that in mind.Ã¢â‚¬Â
Yay! Progress IN SPACE!

CHAPTER 2: DESCENT

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It all looks fine from out here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Copy that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“T minus 45 minutes to de-orbit burn.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Man, you guys should see it out here, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s stunning!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Need I remind you to be careful because youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re on EVA?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You neednÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t; I know the risks. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m just saying that this is one of the most incredible things IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve ever seen.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I recommend you return to the ship, Hans. Final preparations for the landing need to be made, and cannot be carried out without your expertise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Copy that Stanley, but give me a few more minutes to marvel at the planet.Ã¢â‚¬Â

45 minutes laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re clear of the docking port. Engines online.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Stanley, is the descent trajectory plotted?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Affirmative. Please try to follow it as closely as possible.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why wouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t I do that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Unknown.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Then whyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d you say it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It was merely cautionary, nothing more.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cautionary, but unnecessary.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“On the contrary, Franklin, it is part of more core programming to issue warnings and cautions; IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m afraid it is completely necessary.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t thinkÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Franklin, instead of trying to argue with the AI, could you take us down to the surface?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, yes, justÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ hold on, de-orbiting now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Continue along this heading for 2 minutes and 4 seconds. Fuel levels optimal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think this thing should be fine for getting us off the surface again, once weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve transferred the fuel from the rover and habitation modules. Hell, I think itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be fine without.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mission parameters call for the fuel transfer, so we wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t be able to test your thoughts.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t care as long as we can get home again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No doubt that we will, Mernie.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Optimal trajectory achieved. Fuel levels optimal.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the first burn done. Hans, arm the radial engines.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re armed. Parachutes are also ready to deploy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“How many GÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s will the Ã¢â‚¬Ëœchutes put us under?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ probably about 4 or 5, bearing in mind theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be decelerating us from around 500 metres per second to around 20 metres per second.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sounds about right, based on previous Duna missions.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I concur.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, that isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t too bad, I suppose.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, second burn is now under way.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be passing awfully close to the top of the volcanoÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be fine.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Predicted trajectory puts the lander at over 2km from the highest point of the mountain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“See? Plenty of clearance.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok thenÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hngh!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Drogue Ã¢â‚¬Ëœchutes fired.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Man, if you thought that was bad, Mernie, just you wait for the main parachutes.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh noÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HNNGGH!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HmmphÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ main Ã¢â‚¬Ëœchutes fired, drogue Ã¢â‚¬Ëœchutes fully deployed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That hurtÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Probably all the months in zero gravity for you, but it shouldnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t have been that bad, really.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Says the ex-test pilot.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Fair play.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“500 metres from the surface. Please note that the lander has overshot the base site by 1.5km; a hop across the surface will be required.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s the worst part over with now, Mernie.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Unless we crash.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ever the optimist, arenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Mernie: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Expect the worst, but hope for the best.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Hans: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You live by that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Well, over here, it is now 2014. I'm not sure what my resolution will be, if I even decide to go by one, but that is not the point of this message.

A year ago, I believe I was in the midst of reading czokletmuss' Jool AAR. It was, and still is, one of the most captivating stories on the forum. A short while later, and another little story appears about a Duna colony, and that immediately triggered something in my head; an idea, a mission.

It became known as Outreach Colony: The home on Duna. I had little idea what to expect, but I knew I wanted to write this story in the style of czokletmuss. Looking back now, it's the least well written of my stories, but there is something about it that makes it one of my favourites. The Mechani-Kraken plot was definitely unique, but I thought it risky. Nevertheless, I went ahead with it, and what a reception you guys gave me. I'd have probably continued to write Odysseus without such a reception, but I suddenly had this audience that seemed very much interested in my work. It made me determined to write better.

Roll on a few stories later to Resistance: The interplanetary struggle, which I believe now stands as one of my more popular pieces. That final work in my so-called Kraken Saga was pretty intensive to complete, and while I would have loved a massive fleet action at some point, the little battle scenes were pretty laggy, enough to shoot down any hopes of having cruisers everywhere. However, it too stands as a favourite, and you guys certainly seemed to enjoy it.

And then came a new series, following on from the last. I must say, the Venturer Program is complicated. I am really trying to develop my characters more fully, and if the Dres Expedition was anything, it was a significant step in the right direction on that front. Now, Resurgence... again, my characters are developing, and I promise you, the plot will definitely thicken. You'll just have to wait for me to post the chapters

And after all this, I want to thank you guys; czokletmuss for inspiring me to write my own stories, and you lot comprising the audience; I've not read a single negative comment from anyone, which must be good. You've stuck around, and that's more than I could have asked. Heck, I've even inspired some of you, and that's totally mad!

To sum up, thank you all, and Happy New Year. 2014 should be a good one

Rule of Drama says Mernie is already dead.

Woah, dat new year speech... rep for you, good sir.
